posts.name: Sam
posts.cooked: Hello, I am in the early stages of creating a electronics-based code simulation tool, and I am faced with the task of figuring out exactly how every FRC component works so I can model it with a simulation.  I decided to start with the SparkMax.  So, how much do we know about the SparkMax?  Are there circuit diagrams?  Is there any way we can see the software without being chased down by Rev?  Are there existing simulations of it?  What I need is something that will tell me, for a given set of pin inputs, what the SparkMax will output. Thanks for any help you can give.

posts.name: Technologyman00
posts.cooked: You can just look up how a generic bldc controller works

posts.name: Sam
posts.cooked: My goal, though, is to be able to guarantee that the real SparkMax will act in the exact same way as the simulated version.  Is there enough information available to be able to do that?

posts.name: Tim Winters
posts.cooked: Why not just model the motor itself? There’s tons of support for that baked into WPILib

posts.name: Sam
posts.cooked: What do you mean?  I’m aware of the sim classes, but I understand them to be more of a stub than an accurate replica.

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked:
What is your end goal?

It’s largely enough in FRC to model the physics of your mechanism using the various sim classes.

That gets you a pretty high fidelity simulation.

posts.name: Sam
posts.cooked: My goal is to create a code simulation tool that fully emulates the Rio and other hardware, unveiling any hardware-specific issues and allowing my code team to eliminate all hardware interface issues before we get the robot.

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked:
Not trying to put you down, because your motive is admirable, but a lot of hardware interface issues and things rely on the firmware, how it acts, the microcontroller in the motor controller itself and so on. Most of that I imagine is proprietary information.

Simulating at the level you desire is the kind of thing that these vendors do internally for product development and validation. It’s not generally intended for the end user to do such things.

This is a time I’d say it’s better to just validate that sort of stuff for your team with real hardware. Simulation in FRC isn’t really for simulating the exact actions of a device. It’s for simulating the physics of mechanisms.

posts.name: Sam
posts.cooked: That’s a good point, and people have definitely survived without being able to simulate this kind of thing.  Even if it seems unrealistic though, I would like to give this a shot.  If detailed information is proprietary, is there a way to recreate an empirical model through extensive testing?  Can the SparkMaxSim class be inspected and expanded upon?  The first step I have identified is to break apart the CAN signals and figure out what input means what.  Is there at least info about the CAN messages?  Any info from more experienced people would be appreciated.

posts.name: Ryan Blue
posts.cooked:
Paraduks:

The first step I have identified is to break apart the CAN signals and figure out what input means what. Is there at least info about the CAN messages? Any info from more experienced people would be appreciated.

The CAN message schema for the Spark MAX was partially public (in particular, the heartbeat implementation was not) in 2019, but is no longer. There’s a copy of the 2019 vendordep rehosted here . Note that there have been a lot of firmware features added since 2019. However, like others have said, this type of simulation that you’re wanting to do is likely not going to be as useful as you think. There will always be some sort of hardware quirk that you’re not able to simulate, and the amount of effort you’ll need to put in to make it work will almost certainly outweigh the benefit you’ll get from it.

link_counts.title: GitHub - FRC3005/SparkMax-Java-115: Git rehost of REV Spark Max library from v1.1.5 - this is available on REV's website on wayback machine. Hosted here for ease of access.

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked:
What specific problem do you believe this will solve?

I’d say documenting REVLib better is more valuable then trying to simulate a Spark Max/Flex. REV is trying, but not everything is documented. And creating a wrapper for Sparks like many other teams have done (including us).

Doing things in your wrapper like changing the default motor encoder velocity reading settings to make velocity PID more accurate, or doing checks to make sure that each setting is actually applied, etc.

Then testing everything with a test board (a standalone electronics panel with FRC components) or a simple practice bot, to catch bugs and other issues.

That will be a better use of your time than this. Unless your goal is just to learn how to do circuit simulation, though there are better ways of doing that.

posts.name: Sam
posts.cooked: I do like the idea of creating a wrapper.  What improvements have you implemented with yours?  About my motivation for creating circuit simulation—-my team has limited resources, so creating a physical test bed isn’t always possible.  My tool would essentially be a digital test bed—-an application where you can wire up virtual components and run code on them to see if everything is going to work correctly.  This would be useful, not just for my team, but for anyone with limited access to FRC components.  It would democratize FRC coding by making development fully free and fully independent of physical robot parts.
Could you use the existing wpi simulation to do this?

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked:
We’ve done many things in our wrapper library, including making AdvantageKit logging inherent to the object and largely transparent to the programmer.

Custom library for 418 Purple Haze. Contribute to lasarobotics/PurpleLib development by creating an account on GitHub.

As others have said, the necessary data to do this properly isn’t public information. Best you could do is simulate what the motor controller should do, but at that point you’re not gaining anything because you don’t know any of the quirks and can’t simulate them. I’d suggest putting more work into outreach to get the funds necessary to make a test board or practice bot.

And simulating what the motor controller should do when working correctly isn’t valuable because that’s effectively already what’s done when you do regular old FRC simulation.

link_counts.title: GitHub - lasarobotics/PurpleLib: Custom library for 418 Purple Haze

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked: OP’s goal is not to simulate the physics of a mechanism, but the signal responses of devices on a robot (like a smart motor controller) given the commands sent to the device.

posts.name: Sam
posts.cooked: Thanks for the wrapper code, this is something we may implement for next year. This is a bit of a long stretch, but there might be a way to figure out the quirks and nuances of the hardware without having all the details from Rev.  Hypothetically, I could take a physical SparkMax, put every possible set of inputs into it, and record its output.  Then I could create a totally accurate simulated SparkMax just by calling a lookup table.  Might there be a realistically feasible way to do this?  Obviously recording every set of input / output is impossible in the real world, but utilizing an initial understanding of the hardware and a probabilistic / machine learning technique to fill in the gaps, I could hypothetically arrive at a ~99% accurate model of the SparkMax simply through empirical testing.  Any thoughts?

posts.name: Carlos Gross Jones
posts.cooked: You can’t really do that in finite time, because a Spark Max is not combinational logic. It’s based on a microcontroller, with memory and complex behavior.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Mere hours of work can save you entire minutes of planning

posts.custom_user_title: Mere hours of work can save you entire minutes of planning

posts.name: Sam
posts.cooked: That’s a good point.  What if you started with an existing model of the structure and microcontrollers though?  The components within the SparkMax are known.  If you began with a baseline, you should only need to test for flukes or strange software behaviors.  Does anyone know about existing emulators for the microcontrollers within the SparkMax?

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked:
Paraduks:

Does anyone know about existing emulators for the microcontrollers within the SparkMax?

Even if an emulator for the microcontroller exists, the firmware running on it is proprietary to Rev and will likely be quite difficult to get running on an emulator without Rev’s involvement.  Even if you get it running, the actual behavior is going to be difficult to capture in this way, as it likely does high speed sampling of the encoder inputs, etc, and is going to be CPU intensive to emulate accurately.

posts.name: Carlos Gross Jones
posts.cooked:
Paraduks:

Does anyone know about existing emulators for the microcontrollers within the SparkMax?

That’s not your problem. It uses a fairly well-known micro (maybe an ST? I focused more on CTRE products, which use PICs, back when I was doing hacking in this direction.).

First of all, you don’t have access to the firmware source. It may be possible to get the firmware from a Rev .dfu file to your own chip. (IIRC, the Rev firmware file is less obfuscated than the CTRE one.) But you cannot then do any debugging, because you don’t have a build with the debug symbols. All you could really do to get the output is to take the physical output pins (which go to FET drivers on a real Spark) and feed those into a digitizer or FPGA to analyze how hard the firmware thinks it’s driving the motor. If you want to do this in brushless mode, you also have to generate Hall feedback signals in real time to keep the commutation logic happy.

I spent a while trying to develop a system like this. I figured out that I could create an RTL model of a micro with simulated program memory, and then instantiate as many as you want on a big Kintex. You then need to instantiate test harnesses for each virtual motor controller, which fake out the Hall signals and encoder feedback, and create a virtual CAN bus. Then in a computer, you can run physics sim in realtime to figure out how the encoder signals should change.

The reason we’re not using something like that currently is because it’s a lot more trouble than it’s worth. You end up needing a lot of FPGAs, a server with an RTOS, and a ton of hardware and software development effort. To get a virtual Talon running the real Talon firmware, it takes a lot of deep reverse engineering, and some hot nitric acid, and it wouldn’t be legal to share the results anyway.

In the end, it’s a lot easier and cheaper to buy some motor controllers and screw them to a board.
